articles.title: Cardano News Today: Why Investors Are Rushing To Viral Presale As 40,000 Investors Back RTX
articles.author: Crypto Economy
articles.summary: DeFi project RTX has already locked in more than 40,000 holders during its presale. Analysts are calling it the next big altcoin in 2025, comparing its potential to the early Cardano and DeFi projects.

articles.title: Indian businessman seeks police help after $120,000 crypto fraud
articles.author: Cryptopolitan
articles.summary: An Indian businessman has been scammed of up to Rs. 1 crore (approximately $120,000) after investing in a fraudulent crypto investment. He filed a complaint with the police against the accused, who hails from Ahmedabad. The businessman is accusing the scammer of fraud.

articles.title: Bitcoin breaks $125k in one of the quietest rallies ever
articles.author: Cryptoslate
articles.summary: Bitcoin has smashed through the $125,000 level, setting a new Bitcoin all-time high. It was broken on Sunday, but there were no memes, comments or euphoria on social media. It's one of the quietest Bitcoin rallies the market has ever witnessed.

articles.title: 'Sell Shovels': This Firm Makes Dashboards for Strategy and Dozens of Bitcoin Treasuries
articles.author: Bit RSS
articles.summary: As Bitcoin treasury firms proliferate in the U.S., an engineer-by-day is building dashboards for them on the other side of the world, in a project called "Bitcoin Dashboard" in which he's building a dashboard for them.

articles.title: Trader Alex Krüger Says Bitcoin Won't See This Price for a While After Strong BTC Breakout
articles.author: The Daily Hodl
articles.summary: Alex Krüger says Bitcoin is in the midst of a breakout that won't take BTC to lower prices for some time. He thinks that $120,000 will most likely remain in the rearview mirror for the time being after BTC broke out to the $122,000 area.

articles.title: Bitcoin Faces Its 1913 Moment
articles.author: Freedomsphoenix Readerfour
articles.summary: Core and Knots are at war over the Bitcoin network. It's similar to the struggle to establish the Federal Reserve in 1913. The true drivers in 1913 were the same as they are today: a desire for power, profit and the ability to manufacture money from a hard money basis.
